I’m going to ignore the glaring errors with the story, such as it having been 10 years since the accident and they’re still both alone–specifically how she’s a quadruple amputee and somehow taking care of herself living alone–and talk specifically about the psychological signaling. For her to allow all four of her prostheses to be removed is the ultimate act of vulnerability. She can’t possibly put them back on herself; even if she was missing just her arms, she couldn’t get them back on alone. That’s the act of trust being highlighted in the story; her willingness to be put into that state because she trusts the outcome of it. But no, he needs to take far better physical care of himself, and they should’ve just been together from before–and through–the accident. The worldbuilding breaks down otherwise.
